Dhalla, R., Felefele, K.B., Zangoulos, J. Khan, A. Goh, J., Atchinson, D.A., Campbell, C.W.“Imaging the retina at optimal pupil sizes significantly improves resolution and contrast in those with diabetes.” Biophotonics Congress: Optics in the Life Sciences 2023 (OMA, NTM, BODA, OMP, BRAIN), Technical Digest Series (Optica Publishing Group, 2023), paper DTh2A.8.

Articles about learn in public, brag document and free stuffs.
Learn In Public If there’s a golden rule, it’s this one, so I put it first. All the other rules are more or less elaborations of this rule #1.
A habit of creating learning exhaust:
Write blogs and tutorials and cheatsheets. Speak at meetups and conferences. Ask and answer things on Stackoverflow or Reddit. Avoid the walled gardens like Slack and Discord, they’re not public. Make Youtube videos or Twitch streams. Start a newsletter. Draw cartoons. Link Make Free Stuff The best growth hack is still to build something people enjoy, then attaching no strings to it. You’d be surprised how far that can get you.
Make free stuff! The web is still for everyone.
Link
How to hone your new superpower: teaching I learned early in my developer journey that teaching others is an effective way to quickly deepen my understanding of a new concept or technology. I’ve found that needing to articulate a particular concept to others causes me to revisit my assumptions and leads me to do additional research to fill any knowledge gaps.
Link
Your future self will thank you: Building your personal documentation. Developers can take a DRY approach to how they search for answers to questions they encounter multiple times. By relying on an internal database (or “second brain”) they can reduce their reliance on external search engines.
Link
Brag now, remember later: Document your accomplishments Given five minutes notice to summarize your recent professional and personal accomplishments and wins, how detailed would your response be? Would that be enough time for you to sufficiently capture some of the things you’re most proud of from the past few months or years?
Link
The most successful developers share more than they take One of the questions I always ask successful bloggers is: what motivated you to start? The answer is always the same: I did it for myself. Whatever your work, you should embrace the philosophy of “public by default”.
Public-by-default means this: everytime you create something, learn something, or just notice something’s interesting, do it in public. This may seem daunting—writing blog posts, helping the community and transforming ideas from thoughts into words all takes time. But sharing is like a muscle, and by committing to a regular schedule, you become much more efficient. This consistency of volume is also key to reaping the benefits of sharing.
To truly embrace public-by-default, it’s not enough to share your successful projects and knowledge, but additionally to bring the humility to share your learning and failures.
Link
description: Articles about learning in public, brag document and free stuffs.
title: Collections No.1

content: Chhibber, N., Goh, J., and Law, E. (2022) “Teachable Conversational Agents for Crowdwork: Effects on Performance and Trust”, CSCW 2022.

Last year, I met with Rahim, Kaleb and Melanie to discuss how to analyze the data about the eye’s optic. It was an educational moment for me when I found that human vision is different between those with and without diabetes. My learning journey did not end there. I am usually quite hands-on with the data analysis bits, but not this time. Both Rahim and Kaleb analyzed the data and interpreted the results by themselves with minimal guidance from me. I am very proud to see their work at the Canadian Association of Physicist Congress.
title: Retinal Image Quality in Diabetic Patients

content: What a great start to the year! Our paper about teachable conversational agents in crowdwork is accepted to CSCW. Congratulations Nalin! It has been a pleasure to join the team on this long journey.
title: Teachable Conversational Agents
